channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-5580] NativeAuthenticationServiceTest getting multiple errors trying to delete files/directories during teardown
item.description:
Multiple errors during teardown while trying to delete files/directories of the test databases on vista against sun jdk16 on vista, but passed against same jvm on sun nightly runs againstlinux and solaris.

As of time of this report the tests against other sun jvms had not finished. Errors were also seen in ibm nightly runs, I'll rerport those in following comments.

The following checkin that was included in the reported test failures changed the Native authentication tests, so seems likely to have caused the issues:
r1233377 | rhillegas | 2012-01-19 14:51:13 +0100 (Thu, 19 Jan 2012) | 1 line
First version of NATIVE authentication service, including first tranche of tests for it.

vista run had 6 errors:
http://dbtg.foundry.sun.com/derby/test/Daily/jvm1.6/testing/testlog/vista/1233467-suitesAll_diff.txt

item.summary: NativeAuthenticationServiceTest getting multiple errors trying to delete files/directories during teardown

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:

Would appreciate advice from someone who has experience with the problems in deleting test directories on Windows platforms. Thanks.

To me it looks like the database hasn't been properly shut down before it is being deleted (due to the high number of files/dirs, 77, having open file handles).

A similar problem was seen with the istat daemon, and in that case it was only one file being left open. What I'm trying to say is that an attempt to shut down the database may have happened, i.e. a connection with shutdown=true has been made, but things may still not have been shut down due to a bug in the [new] code. It can also be a simpler case where the database is active at the time of deletion.

Just a shot in the dark, but can the changes to the test decorators have caused this?

the main difference on windows with other OS's that I have seen is that you can't delete files that another process has open. With
Derby this usually means the database is still up and likely the files are in cache.

I haven't been involved in the past fixes other than reviewing some changes related to retrying the delete. Hopefully some others
can comment on specific junit fixes that have helped in the past.

Could you describe at high level what one of the test fixtures that is failing is doing. Does it start multiple databases? Does it start other processes
that then start Derby? Maybe there is some missing shutdown or there needs to be some extra wait for something to finish.

Another thing that sometimes happens is that there is some either intended or unintended dependency between the tests fixtures and the order they are run. This
order can be different across jvms/OS's unless you specifically program the order in.

It's likely that these tests are using the decorators in an order which hasn't been stressed before. The tests create a lot of single-use databases, which are deleted between test runs. The tests also shut down the engine. The order of cleanup steps should be:

1) Bring down the engine.

2) Delete the database directories without explicitly shutting down the databases.

The tests behave like this because one of the databases, the credentials database, is needed in order to authenticate the request to shutdown the engine. The credentials database has to still exist when the request to shutdown the engine is processed. The engine needs to be down before the next test runs so that the next test will create its own system-wide authentication service.

Is the directory deletion blocked by open file handles? Are files not being released because engine shutdown precedes directory deletion? Thanks.

These tests continue to fail across all ibm jvms run against window platforms. It looks like there is problem with the sun public tests, so have not seen any results on any other sun jvm since the original report.

Let's give this another day or two to see if someone with access to Windows platforms can spare some cycles for this. I don't have such a platform, so all I can do is provide advice about what the tests are supposed to do and, if necessary, disable them on Windows. Thanks.

+1 for disabling, nobody seems to be aware of a quick fix at this point.

A cursory look at some of the test code reveals that three databases (the number of databases that can't be deleted) are being wrapped in TestConfiguration.additionalDatabaseDecoratorNoShutdown. Both the embedded and the client/server run fail.
Why are these databases not being shut down by the decorator?
If deliberate, where are they being explicitly shut down?
From the decorator method:
new DropDatabaseSetup(test, logicalDbName)
{
protected void tearDown() throws Exception

{ // the test is responsible for shutdown removeDatabase(); <------ this is probably what fails }

},

The test fails in my environment also if I just run the NativeAuthenticationServiceTest fixture. I can post the results if anyone is interested. Same set of failures as seen in nighly's. I didn't see anything interesting in the saved derby.log. The detailed result log show 3 retries on all the files with no incremental success in the deletion.

you asked/commented:

> 2) Delete the database directories without explicitly shutting down the databases.
I don't think any test that expects to be able to delete directories and/or files of database while the database is
still up will work across all OS's.

> Is the directory deletion blocked by open file handles? Are files not being released because engine shutdown
> precedes directory deletion? Thanks.
I believe directory deletion will be blocked by open file handles, I don't know if that is the problem here.

I would have thought that "engine shutdown" would have closed the open file handles but not sure. What exactly
does engine shutdown translate to in our junit test harness to what the server actually does.

Looks like the engine shutdown is performed indirectly by using a SystemPropertyTestSetup:

//
// Turn on the property which enables NATIVE authentication. This will trigger
// an engine shutdown at the end of the test. We want to shutdown the engine
// before deleting the physical databases. This is because we need one of the
// databases (the credentials db) in order to authenticate engine shutdown.
//
Properties systemProperties = nast.systemProperties( credentialsDBPhysicalName );
if ( systemProperties != null )

{ result = new SystemPropertyTestSetup( result, systemProperties, true ); }

However, for the set of tests where nast.systemProperties() returns null, such a decorator is not added.

Maybe the attached patch (d5580-shutdown-engine.diff) does the trick? It adds another decorator that explicitly calls shutdownEngine() if there's no SystemPropertyTestSetup.

Thanks for testing the patch, Mike. I found a Windows box where I could test it myself, and found that it seemed to work both when running the test standalone and as part of the larger test suite, so I went ahead and committed the changes (revision 1235709).

As to the problems with applying the patch, the paths in patches produced by git have a different root than those produced by svn, so one needs to pass -p1 to the patch command to get them to apply, instead of -p0 as one would do with patches produced by svn.
Thanks for that simple solution, Knut. Cheers.
